H0.text: A levee is formed when sediments that have been carried long distances by rivers and streams are deposited at the mouth of a river.

H1.text: A gully is formed when sediments are deposited at the mouth of a river, where rivers and streams can carry sediments long distances before they are deposited.

H2.text: A delta is formed when rivers and streams deposit sediments at their mouth.

H3.text: A rift is formed when sediments are carried by rivers and streams long distances before they are deposited at the mouth of a river.

A4.text: At the mouth of a river, the change in flow conditions can cause the river to drop any sediment it is carrying. This sediment deposition can generate a variety of landforms, such as deltas, sand bars, spits, and tie channels.

A5.text: As a result, sediment drops out of the flow and is deposited as alluvium, which builds up to form the river delta.
